[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms a robotic arm with a gripper positioned near a human wrist/forearm. The image shows a robotic end-effector approaching a person's arm resting on a wooden table surface. The environment appears to be a technical workspace with computers and equipment visible.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The robot's wrist frame is shown with three colored axes - red (+X), green (+Y), and blue (+Z) - indicating the direction of positive motion along each axis relative to the robot's end-effector.
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to upward motion in the world space, pointing vertically upward from the robot's gripper. Positive Z motion would move the gripper upward away from the table, while negative Z would push downward toward the table surface.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move slightly in the negative Z direction to apply downward pressure on the dislocated wrist joint, helping to guide it back into position.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward motion (toward the person) in the world space. Positive X extends outward from the gripper toward the person's arm, while negative X would pull back toward the robot base.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move in the positive X direction to apply gentle pressure along the length of the forearm, guiding the dislocated joint back into its socket.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to rightward motion in the world space (from the robot's perspective). Positive Y points to the right side of the image, while negative Y would move to the left.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move with minimal motion, primarily maintaining position to stabilize the wrist laterally while the primary repositioning occurs along the X and Z axes.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with a combination of downward pressure (negative Z) and forward motion (positive X) while maintaining lateral stability (minimal Y movement) to guide the dislocated wrist joint back into proper anatomical alignment.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 15 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert no force along the Y-axis with magnitude 0 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 20 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert no torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert clockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 2 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force: Moderate grasping force is needed to securely hold the wrist without causing discomfort or tissue damage, accounting for the need to manipulate a human joint with care while providing enough stability to guide it back into place, thus 15 to 25 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist and forearm with soft tissue, estimated mass of segment being manipulated is 1.2kg, moderate friction coefficient against robot gripper of approximately 0.6, requiring careful handling due to biological tissue"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply downward pressure (negative Z) combined with forward motion (positive X) while stabilizing laterally (minimal Y) to guide the dislocated wrist joint back into anatomical alignment"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [30, 0, -15]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [15, 0, -20, 0, -2, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 20
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 3.5
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
